newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Germany says Poland leads NATO candidates.
newsitem.headline: Germany says Poland leads NATO candidates.

text.p: Germany endorsed Poland's application for membership of NATO and the European Union on Tuesday, with Defence Minister Volker Ruehe saying it was the leading candidate among countries seeking to join.

"Poland is a country where there are no doubts at all that they are very much at the forefront when it comes to becoming a member of NATO and also a member of the European Union," Ruehe told reporters in Canberra.
Germany is the second NATO member in a week to support Poland's application for membership. Last week British Prime Minister John Major described Poland as a primary applicant.
U.S. President Bill Clinton last week called for the first former East Bloc states to join NATO when it marks its 50th anniversary in 1999.
But Ruehe said there were more applicants than positions immediately available. "It is very clear already now that not all countries can be accepted," he said.
Russia objects to the eastern expansion of NATO. Its foreign minister, Yevgeny Primakov, responded to Clinton's speech last week by saying Russia had a negative attitude to the proposed expansion.
Poland hopes to gain admission to the European Union by 2000, although the European Commission has nominated 2002 as a more realistic target.
Ruehe was in Canberra for talks with the Australian government.
